title: Disable UTF-8 input/percent encoding when using a search shortcut
content:
I've added a search shortcut for Wayback Machine where %s is the URL I need to search: https://web.archive.org/web/*/%s

But Firefox automatically encodes my URL; for example, when I copy-paste https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/ to search its archives with the shortcut, it is automatically encoded with UTF-8: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https%3A%2F%2Fwww.mozilla.org%2Fen-US%2F whereas I want it to lead me to https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/.

I've googled around and haven't found a solution to this, and setting "browser.urlbar.decodeURLsOnCopy" to "true" only decodes it correctly when copied. The extension I've used to add the WM search shortcut gives me an option to encode input differently than default UTF-8, but I don't know how would I use it to disable encoding altogether. See attached pictures.

title: Icons have just become smaller with a WIDE white space after update - can it be reversed?
content:
I posted this very same headline about seven months ago and a contributor called jscher2000 provided an awesome solution:-

In short it involved Double-clicking the browser.newtabpage.activity-stream.newNewtabExperience.enabled preference to switch the value from true to false

It instantly solved the problem of having tiny little icons surrounded by a HUGE border of wated white space - the result of an "upgrade".

Alas, I made the mistake of allowing FF to upgrade again and now the tiles are shrunk back to a level where people like me who are blind as a bat, cannot really see what the icons are any more.

I checked and the original solution is still set to "FALSE", but Firefox is now ignoring that.

I realise that someone has decided this looks "cooler" or "sleeker" so we should have no choice in the matter anymore, - it's just a shame that it is also far harder for people with grotty vision. The obsession with changing things from clear and simple to "smart but difficult" seems so silly.

Other than re-installing an older version and not making the mistake of letting it "upgrade" to a less useful version again, is there anything I can do to make it so I can still actually SEE the contents of the tiles - other than buy stronger glass and get used to even more wasted white-space?

Is there are new way to fix the broken "improvement" please ?

title: Resolution of strange server error after upgrade to Mac OS 10.15.7 and subsequent security download
content:
Previously reported denial of account access via password for Hughes.net was resolved by downloading a clean copy of Firefox 97.0 using the most recent .dmg. by using an old Firefox .dmg (version 66.0.2) to create a "clean" version with no add-ons. Erasing the interim version enabled a pristine download to be substituted. Then re-installing both the new Firefox and the previously associated DuckDuckGo add-on overcame the previous bug. It is not known whether the upgrade to OS 10.15.7 itself caused the password entry bug directly with Firefox operation or whether the problem was a combination with the Mac version of DuckDuckGo processing.

It should be noted that 17 other 64 bit third party apps were broken by this MacOS upgrade and had to be reinstalled using previously saved or newly downloaded .dmg files. Most of these other broken apps would not even boot at all. Accident or Planned ?

Either way, thanks for allowing me to vent my fury at Apple on your platform. -D. Meisel, Geneseo,NY

title: Firefox ran stably and reliably till last Friday, has been broken ever since
content:
Since last Friday I have been experiencing an ongoing issue with the Firefox application. Simply put I opened the application and all I saw was a blank screen, I still had the basic format/layout but nothing was coming up including error messages. The weird thing is is that I am experiencing the same issue on both my computer and laptop, both run windows 10 and are up to date on software. I verified that the antivirus/firewall isn't interfering with the application, other web browsers are functioning properly, I have uninstalled and reinstalled Firefox, cookies have been cleared, Firefox has been refreshed, computer restarted, new Firefox profile created, and verified by Webroot and Windows Defender that no malware is present.

I tried troubleshooting more today and I was able to at least get a webpage to load, but if I tried visiting another webpage in that same tab, Firefox would hang up. What allowed me to get a webpage to load (at least the first one) was by disabling the webroot extension. I've attempted to run Firefox with all extensions disabled but I am still having the same issue.

Other features that wont work are tools under the more tools tab, I was able to get the browser console open and took a screenshot of that, hopefully that may shed some light on the issue, any help would be great appreciated, thanks!

title: Firefox Crash at Hughesnet account sign-on after upgrade to Mac OS 10.15 Described as internal server error
content: Folks: After two days of a rather difficult upgrade to Mac OS 10.15 from 10.14 on an older 27 inch iMac, many programs had to be reloaded from .dmg files. Today I downloaded the latest "security" update for Apple for OS 10.15 but since I do not have any "devices" that run IOS, etc. , I declined the accompianying device update. My copy of Firefox for the Mac was regenerated and the same server error was observed. Yet when I used the "new" Safari I could get through to my Hughesnet account information. I hate Safari and have not used it for years, but this is obviously Apple's way of trying to force all Apple users to use it in preference to other browsers. I am hoping you can track this problem down. I would have contacted Hughes support, but since Safari got through, I am sure Hughes support could not help. What is strange is that other than being unable to sign on the account, Firefox behaves normally getting into other sites. You may also be interested to know why I upgraded to 10.14 in the first place when 10.14 was working just fine (again without an iPad or an iPhone (I have neither) associated with the iMac. I was considering switching from Turbotax to HR-Block, but found out that H-R Block's program demanded using Safari ! So after using turbotax for nearly 15 years I went back and found 2021 required an upgrade to OS 10.15. Thus I got caught in a dominoe effect trying to avoid Safari and then Safari comes back to haunt me. How is that for irony ? Anyway best wishes and thanks for whatever you can do if anything. -D. title: 97.0 Can't Save Web page Images via Tools > Page Info > Media > Save As
content:
This is on Version 97.0, latest release, Upgraded on Feb 15, 2022

Web page Image Download via Tools > Page Info > Media > Save As - no longer works as it did in previous versions of Firefox.

Attempting to save any image results in no file saved.

How to Duplicate Note: Download setting is set to: Always ask you where to save files

1. Go to new tab (My default is Firefox home) 2. Select from tool bar Tools > Page Info > Media 3. Select any image in the list (it will give you a preview) 4. Select the Save As button 5. Windows directory screen will ask you to choose the directory 6. Select Save As Results: Windows directory screen will disappear as if the file was saved, but checking the directory reveals that no file was saved.

This was supposedly fixed in Bug 1683244 ( https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1683244 ) but it seems to have reappeared.
